Award.AwardTitle: NSF NPGI Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds a National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship for FY 2012. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow to focus their studies in plant genomics with an emphasis on quantitative genetics, modern breeding approaches, and bioinformatics. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Cory D. Hirsch is "A Systems Biology Approach to Understanding Anthocyanin Biosynthesis and Regulation in Potato". The host institution for the fellowship is Michigan State University and the sponsoring scientists are Drs. Robin Buell and David Douches.

Anthocyanins, the purple and red pigments found in plants, have numerous health benefits including a high anti-oxidant content with human health benefits. The scientific goals of the proposed research is to investigate anthocyanin production at the genetic, biochemical, molecular, and systems level in potato, a crop species that is emerging as an important component of the 21st century world food needs. This project will couple classical plant breeding approaches with modern technology enabled genome-wide approaches to generate and integrate multiple data types to provide a genome-scale understanding of the mechanisms by which genes govern anthocyanin production in potato.

Training objectives include classical breeding, biochemistry, quantitative genetics and plant genomics. Broader impacts include capacity-building and advanced training for students from the United States to engage in interdisciplinary research in plant improvement and associated sciences such as physiology, quantitative genetics, and computational biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The title of this NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology was “A systems biology approach to understanding anthocyanin biosynthesis and regulation in potato”. Anthocyanins, the purple and red pigments found in plants, have numerous health benefits including a high anti-oxidant content with human health benefits. The scientific goals of the proposed research was to investigate anthocyanin production at the genetic, biochemical, molecular, and systems level in potato, a crop species that is emerging as an important component of the 21st century world food needs. This project coupled classical plant breeding approaches with modern technology enabled genome-wide approaches to generate and integrate multiple data types to provide a genome-scale understanding of the mechanisms by which genes govern anthocyanin production in potato. The data resulting from the fellowship will help towards breeding potato clones high in anythocyanins in a focused, educated, and efficient manner. In addition to scientific merit of this project, the project promoted teaching, learning, and training. Participants in the project were directly involved in designing and instructing multiple computational biology workshops for undergraduate and graduate students interested in obtaining necessary skills for scientific advancement.

 

This project provided training by contributing funds for participants to attend educational workshops, as well as provided the ability for researchers to travel to multiple expert laboratories throughout the country for further training. In addition, multiple scientific meetings were attending were the results of this project were disseminated to the larger scientific community.

 

To accomplish the main objective of the project gene expression for every gene was evaluated from contrasting pigmented and non-pigmented potato tuber flesh tissue, leaf tissue, and flower tissue. Along with this data, we identified the specific compounds responsible for purple and red pigmentation in various tissues. By using a large scale data analysis workflow, the project was able to determine genes important for the synthesis and regulation of pigmentation in potato. We also determined compounds responsible for pigmentation can differ between different plant tissues. For example, potato tuber flesh tissue might be purple due to a certain compound, whereas potato leaf tissue from the same palnt might be purple due to a totally different compound. This indicates that anthocyanin production is a complex pathway. Including large datasets that can be utilized by other researchers throughout the world, the techniques and principles employed in this project can be put to use to further the understanding of other important plant chemical pathways, for instance medicinal compounds. Lastly, this project provided to the larger scientific community limitations and cautions for analyzing gene expression data biologically.
